The ECB has announced its PEPP will be increased by EUR 600bn (higher than market expectations) and will be extended at least until June 2021. It is a strong signal sent to the market that the ECB will do whatever it takes to support the recovery.

Brazil retail sales are out at minus 1.3% YoY in March. This is the worst print since the 2015-16 recession. We expect a double-digit decrease in retail sales in April due to the spread of the virus & the implementation of lockdown measures at state-level https://t.co/9VfAeNhx5j

The EC is due to present a draft budget & coronavirus plan today. It should clarify the debate about loans vs grants & also highlight key projects/sectors that could receive financing (i.e. airlines). Official total amount is at €1.5tr but as usual the devil is in the detail.
At 8:00 GMT today, the German Constitutional Court is likely to side with the ECB, but what if…https://t.co/B5T9vLM05a

ECB presser: Eurozone recession between 5% and 12% in 2020. Strong message to Italy: PEPP is perfectly doing the job without the need for ESM and OMT is still here in last resort.
Still terrible data in the US. Initial claims fell to 3,839K from 4,442K, above the consensus, 3,500K. The Q1 employment costs index rose 0.8%, above the consensus, 0.6%.

After 16 hours of unsuccessful negotiations, the Eurogroup is suspended. Italy and the Netherlands are still at loggerheads. The discussion  should resume on Thursday. The press conference that was initially scheduled at 10 AM (Brussels Time) is canceled. https://t.co/AHShvmy218

Breaking news: the Eurogroup is suspended after 16 hours of discussions. Negotiations should start again on Thursday. In the interim, pressure is increasing on the Netherlands and Italy to agree on the draft deal that was reached out around 1am last night.

NFP are out at minus 701K vs expected -100K and unemployment rate jumps from 3.5% in Feb to 4.4% in March. However, it is key to remember that it does not show all the impact from the COVID-19 due to the methodology. The “real” unemployment rate is likely closer to 9-10%.

U.S. initial jobless claims surge again. However, it is unlikely that the NFP report will reflect well labor market disruption as the Labor Department's surveys have been done before most of the containment measures went into effect. https://t.co/EFkV7ZGOU9

Inflation expectations are still subdued, but the risk is increasing fast that food supply chain disruptions due to protectionism and logistical hurdles will lead to higher inflation in the coming weeks and months. Access to the analysis: https://t.co/7hxYKIaqLz https://t.co/R7oPxA5thf

If we make the assumption that net job losses reach 5M this month, which may be very optimistic, the unemployment rate could jump from 3.5% in February to almost 7% in March. ://www.home.saxo/content/articles/macro/us-jobless-claims--a-nightmare-scenario-is-unfolding-26032020
